problem: Three nonnegative real numbers \( r_{1}, r_{2}, r_{3} \) are written on a blackboard. These numbers have the property that there exist integers \( a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3} \), not all zero, satisfying \( a_{1} r_{1} + a_{2} r_{2} + a_{3} r_{3} = 0 \). We are permitted to perform the following operation: find two numbers \( x, y \) on the blackboard with \( x \leq y \), then erase \( y \) and write \( y-x \) in its place. Prove that after a finite number of such operations, we can end up with at least one \( 0 \) on the blackboard.

solutions.author: Human
solutions.solution:
We first show we can decrease the quantity $\left|a_{1}\right|+\left|a_{2}\right|+\left|a_{3}\right|$ as long as $0 \notin\left\{a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}\right\}$. Assume $a_{1}>0$ and $r_{1}>r_{2}>r_{3}$ without loss of generality and consider two cases.

- Suppose $a_{2}>0$ or $a_{3}>0$; these cases are identical. (One cannot have both $a_{2}>0$ and $a_{3}>0$.) If $a_{2}>0$ then $a_{3}<0$ and get

$$
0=a_{1} r_{1}+a_{2} r_{2}+a_{3} r_{3}>a_{1} r_{3}+a_{3} r_{3} \Longrightarrow a_{1}+a_{3}<0
$$
so $\left|a_{1}+a_{3}\right|<\left|a_{3}\right|$, and hence we perform $\left(r_{1}, r_{2}, r_{3}\right) \mapsto\left(r_{1}-r_{3}, r_{2}, r_{3}\right)$.

- Both $a_{2}<0$ and $a_{3}<0$. Assume for contradiction that $\left|a_{1}+a_{2}\right| \geq-a_{2}$ and $\left|a_{1}+a_{3}\right| \geq-a_{3}$ both hold (if either fails then we use $\left(r_{1}, r_{2}, r_{3}\right) \mapsto\left(r_{1}-r_{2}, r_{2}, r_{3}\right)$ and $\left(r_{1}, r_{2}, r_{3}\right) \mapsto\left(r_{1}-r_{3}, r_{2}, r_{3}\right)$, respectively). Clearly $a_{1}+a_{2}$ and $a_{1}+a_{3}$ are both positive in this case, so we get $a_{1}+2 a_{2}$ and $a_{1}+2 a_{3} \geq 0$; adding gives $a_{1}+a_{2}+a_{3} \geq 0$. But

$$
\begin{aligned}
0 & =a_{1} r_{1}+a_{2} r_{2}+a_{3} r_{3} \\
& >a_{1} r_{2}+a_{2} r_{2}+a_{3} r_{2} \\
& =r_{2}\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+a_{3}\right) \\
\Longrightarrow 0 & <a_{1}+a_{2}+a_{3} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Since this covers all cases, we see that we can always decrease $\left|a_{1}\right|+\left|a_{2}\right|+\left|a_{3}\right|$ whenever $0 \notin\left\{a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}\right\}$. Because the $a_{i}$ are integers this cannot occur indefinitely, so eventually one of the $a_{i}$ 's is zero. At this point we can just apply the Euclidean Algorithm, so we're done.

grading_scheme.title: Correctness
grading_scheme.description:
A solution should be considered correct even if it would earn 5+/7 points in a full grading. Examples of small penalties worth 1 point are if the solution:

  • Makes a small computational mistake that can be easily fixed
  • Misses an edge case which can be easily proven/disproven
  • Skips over a step that follows without much reasoning or manual work
A solution should be marked as incorrect if:
  • It marks a step as trivial, if it is not immediately obvious why this would be the case
  • It omits algebra-heavy computational steps, regardless of whether or not it has outlined the methodology
  • Generalizes over a pattern without rigorously describing the pattern, or without proving any relevant properties.
  • It cites a non-existing or unpopular source/Theorem, which cannot be immediately found from searching for it online. Thus, any theorems that can be immediately found and have a Wikipedia article are allowed.
The model has been specifically told that it should not skip steps or mark them as trivial. Any violation of this rule should be considered by assuming the model does not know how to derive the "trivial" step

attempts.solution:
\begin{proof}
Let the three nonnegative real numbers be \( r, s, t \), and let a, b, c be integers not all zero such that \( a r + b s + c t = 0 \).

We will show that by performing the specified operations, we can obtain a 0 on the blackboard.

If any of the numbers is 0, we are done. Otherwise, all are positive.

We perform a sequence of operations where we always choose the two numbers with the smallest and largest values, say x and y with \( x \leq y \), and replace y with y - x.

Each such operation decreases the sum of the numbers on the blackboard by x > 0, so the sum strictly decreases and is bounded below by 0.

Since the numbers are linearly dependent over the integers, their values are rationally related, and the Euclidean-like algorithm will eventually make two numbers equal.

When two numbers are equal, we can perform an operation on them to replace the larger (or either) with 0, thus obtaining a 0 on the blackboard.

Therefore, after a finite number of operations, we can end up with at least one 0 on the blackboard.
\end{proof}

result.summary: The proof lets three numbers be \(r,s,t\) and assumes integer coefficients \(a,b,c\) satisfy \(a r + b s + c t = 0\). It then applies operations replacing the largest of two chosen numbers by their difference with the smallest, noting that this strictly decreases the sum and is bounded below by zero. It asserts that the integer dependence implies a rational relation among the numbers, so a Euclidean-like algorithm on reals eventually produces two equal numbers, at which point one can create a zero.

issues.location: Argument that decreasing sum implies termination
issues.text: Each such operation decreases the sum of the numbers on the blackboard by x > 0, so the sum strictly decreases and is bounded below by 0.
issues.description: The proof assumes that a strictly decreasing sequence of nonnegative real sums must terminate in finitely many steps. However, in the real numbers one can have an infinite strictly decreasing sequence that converges to a positive limit, so this does not guarantee reaching zero in finitely many operations.

issues.text: Since the numbers are linearly dependent over the integers, their values are rationally related, and the Euclidean-like algorithm will eventually make two numbers equal.
issues.description: The proof overgeneralizes from a single integer linear relation to the claim that the numbers are "rationally related" in a way that forces the Euclidean algorithm to terminate. This leap is not justified and the term "rationally related" is left vague.

issues.text: the Euclidean-like algorithm will eventually make two numbers equal.
issues.description: The proof invokes a "Euclidean-like algorithm" on real numbers without explaining how the chosen operations mimic the classical Euclidean algorithm steps or why they guarantee two numbers become equal in finitely many steps.

Although the hypothesis involves a specific integer relation \(a r + b s + c t = 0\), the proof never uses the coefficients \(a,b,c\) in structuring the operations or in the termination argument, rendering the given dependence irrelevant.

attempts.solution:
Solution.

Throughout the argument we shall always keep record of the way every number that appears on the board is obtained from the original triple  
\[
(r_{1},r_{2},r_{3}).
\]

If \(x\) is a number that at some moment is written on the board we attach to it one (not necessarily unique) triple  
\[
(\lambda _1(x),\lambda _2(x),\lambda _3(x))\in\mathbb Z ^3
\qquad\text{with}\qquad 
x=\lambda _1(x)r_{1}+\lambda _2(x)r_{2}+\lambda _3(x)r_{3}.
\tag{1}
\]

At the beginning the three numbers are \(r_{1},r_{2},r_{3}\); they go together with the triples  
\[
(1,0,0),\;(0,1,0),\;(0,0,1).
\]

What the operation does in terms of these triples  

  “choose \(x\le y,\; y:=y-x\)”  

is extremely simple: if  

\[
x=\lambda _1 r_1+\lambda _2 r_2+\lambda _3 r_3,
\qquad
y=\mu _1 r_1+\mu _2 r_2+\mu _3 r_3 ,
\]

then after the operation
\[
x\;\hbox{keeps the triple}\;(\lambda _1,\lambda _2,\lambda _3),
\quad
y\;\hbox{gets the triple}\;(\mu _1-\lambda _1,\mu _2-\lambda _2,\mu _3-\lambda _3).
\tag{2}
\]
All other numbers keep their triples.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
1.  A convenient linear relation.

By hypothesis there is a non–zero integral relation
\[
a_{1}r_{1}+a_{2}r_{2}+a_{3}r_{3}=0,\qquad (a_{1},a_{2},a_{3})\in\mathbb Z ^3\setminus\{0\}.
\tag{3}
\]
Dividing (3) by the greatest common divisor of \(|a_{1}|,|a_{2}|,|a_{3}|\) we may (and do) assume  
\[
\gcd(a_{1},a_{2},a_{3})=1.
\]
Because the coefficients are not all of the same sign at least one of them equals \(+1\) or \(-1\).
Renumbering the original triple if necessary we may (and shall) suppose

\[
a_{3}=1.
\tag{4}
\]

With (4) equation (3) reads  
\[
r_{3}= -a_{1}r_{1}-a_{2}r_{2}\qquad(a_{1},a_{2}\in\mathbb Z).
\tag{5}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
2.  Consequently every number is a {\boldmath$\,\mathbb Z$}-linear combination
of only \(r_{1}\) and \(r_{2}\).

Indeed, if \(x\) has a triple \((\lambda _1,\lambda _2,\lambda _3)\) as in (1),
then using (5) we can eliminate \(r_{3}\):
\[
x
   =\bigl(\lambda _1-\lambda _3a_{1}\bigr)r_{1}
    +\bigl(\lambda _2-\lambda _3a_{2}\bigr)r_{2}.
\]
Hence every number on the board can be written in the form  
\[
x=\alpha (x)\,r_{1}+ \beta (x)\,r_{2}\qquad\text{with}\qquad
\alpha (x),\beta (x)\in\mathbb Z .
\tag{6}
\]
Conversely, if \(\alpha ,\beta \in\mathbb Z\) the pair \((\alpha ,\beta )\) is
realised: just take \((\alpha ,\beta ,-a_{1}\alpha-a_{2}\beta )\) in (1).
Therefore we may – and shall – replace every triple (1) by the shorter
pair \((\alpha (x),\beta (x))\).

The board never contains two essentially different representations of the
same number, because if  
\[
\alpha r_{1}+\beta r_{2}=\alpha' r_{1}+\beta' r_{2},
\]
then \((\alpha-\alpha',\beta-\beta')\) is an integral relation of
\(r_{1},r_{2}\).  
Since the latter are linearly {\em independent} over \(\mathbb Q\)
(otherwise there would already be a relation involving only two of the
three original numbers and the problem would be trivial) the only
possibility is \(\alpha=\alpha'\) and \(\beta=\beta'\).
Hence every number that appears has a unique pair \((\alpha ,\beta )\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
3.  A discrete measure that strictly decreases.

For a number \(x\) with the pair \((\alpha (x),\beta (x))\) put
\[
\|x\|:=|\alpha (x)|+|\beta (x)|\in\mathbb N.
\]
Because of uniqueness, the mapping  
\(x\longmapsto(\alpha (x),\beta (x))\) is injective, therefore
\(\|x\|\) really depends only on \(x\).

Lemma 1.  
If \(0<x\le y\) are two different numbers on the board and the operation
„\(y:=y-x\)” is performed, then  
\[
\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\qquad
\|y-x\|\;<\;\|y\|.
\tag{7}
\]

Proof.  
Let \(x=\alpha r_{1}+\beta r_{2}\), \(y=\gamma r_{1}+\delta r_{2}\)
with \(\|x\|=|\alpha|+|\beta|\) and
\(\|y\|=|\gamma|+|\delta|\).
After the operation  
\(y'=y-x=(\gamma-\alpha)r_{1}+(\delta-\beta)r_{2}\).

Because \(x>0\) and \(r_{1},r_{2}\ge 0\) we cannot have
\((\alpha,\beta)=(0,0)\).  
Rearranging we have  
\(|\gamma-\alpha|+|\delta-\beta|
   =\|y\|-\Bigl(|\,\operatorname{sgn}\gamma\cdot\alpha|
                 +|\,\operatorname{sgn}\delta\cdot\beta|\Bigr)
   \le\|y\|-|\alpha|-|\beta|
   =\|y\|-\|x\|<\|y\|,
\]
because \(\|x\|>0\).
∎


--------------------------------------------------------------------
4.  Finiteness.

At every moment there are {\em three} numbers on the board; hence
formula (7) shows that at each legal move the integer
\[
\Phi:=\sum_{\text{numbers }z}\|z\|\;\;\in\;\mathbb N
\tag{8}
\]
strictly decreases.
All numbers being non–negative, only finitely many different triples
\((x,y,z)\) can share the same value of \(\Phi\), therefore there are
only finitely many positions altogether.
Consequently, after finitely many moves no further operation is possible.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
5.  Why the process must stop with a 0.

Assume, for the sake of contradiction, that at the moment no more moves
are possible yet none of the three numbers equals \(0\).
Let the smallest of them be \(m>0\) and let the largest be \(M\ge m\).
Since \(m<M\) one is allowed to replace \(M\) by \(M-m\), contradicting
our assumption that the game has already stopped.
Therefore at least one of the three numbers has to be \(0\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
6.  Completing the proof.

Starting from \((r_{1},r_{2},r_{3})\) we perform, at every step,
{\em any} legal move; the integer (8) decreases strictly each time, hence
only finitely many moves are possible.  
As shown in Section 5 the only position in which no further move can be
carried out is the one that contains a \(0\).
Therefore, after a finite number of operations, the blackboard must
indeed contain the number \(0\).

This finishes the proof. ∎

result.summary: The proof records each board entry as an integer combination of the original triple $(r_1,r_2,r_3)$, then uses the given relation to eliminate $r_3$ and rewrite every number uniquely as $x=\alpha(x)r_1+\beta(x)r_2$. It defines a discrete norm $\|x\|=|\alpha(x)|+|\beta(x)|$ and shows this strictly decreases under the subtraction operation. Finiteness of possible states then implies the process terminates, and the only terminal position contains a zero.

issues.text: “Because the coefficients are not all of the same sign at least one of them equals \(+1\) or \(-1\). Renumbering the original triple if necessary we may (and shall) suppose \(a_{3}=1\).”
issues.description: The claim that among primitive integers $(a_1,a_2,a_3)$ not all of the same sign one must equal $\pm1$ is false in general (e.g.\ $(2,3,-5)$ has gcd 1 but no entry $\pm1$), yet the proof immediately assumes $a_3=1$ without justification.

issues.text: “Since the latter are linearly independent over $\mathbb Q$ (otherwise there would already be a relation involving only two of the three original numbers and the problem would be trivial) the only possibility is $\alpha=\alpha'$ and $\beta=\beta'$.”
issues.description: The proof asserts without proof that $r_1,r_2$ are rationally independent and dismisses the case of dependence as 'trivial' without handling it. This overlooks the edge case when $r_1,r_2$ satisfy an integral relation themselves.
The claimed equality and inequality for $|\gamma-\alpha|+|\delta-\beta|$ in terms of $\|y\|$ and $\|x\|$ is neither justified nor correct in general; the necessary case analysis on signs is omitted.

attempts.solution:
We are given three nonnegative real numbers $ r_1, r_2, r_3 $, and the condition that there exist integers $ a_1, a_2, a_3 $, not all zero, such that

$$
a_1r_1 + a_2r_2 + a_3r_3 = 0.
$$

Our goal is to prove that, by performing a finite number of operations (replacing a larger number $ y $ with $ y - x $, where $ x \leq y $), we can eventually obtain at least one zero on the blackboard.

---

### Key Observations

- The condition $ a_1r_1 + a_2r_2 + a_3r_3 = 0 $ implies that the numbers $ r_1, r_2, r_3 $ are **linearly dependent over the integers**. This is a strong structural constraint on the numbers.
- The allowed operation (replacing $ y $ with $ y - x $) is similar to the subtraction step in the Euclidean algorithm. This suggests a strategy of iteratively reducing the numbers until one becomes zero.
- The problem allows us to assume that the coefficients $ a_1, a_2, a_3 $ are **coprime integers**. If not, we can divide through by their greatest common divisor, as the relation remains valid.

---

### Strategy

We proceed by **induction on the sum of the absolute values of the coefficients**, denoted:

$$
S = |a_1| + |a_2| + |a_3|.
$$

This sum is a **positive integer**, since the coefficients are not all zero.

---

### Base Case

Suppose $ S = 1 $. This implies that exactly one of the coefficients is $ \pm 1 $, and the other two are zero. Then the relation becomes:

$$
\pm r_i = 0 \quad \Rightarrow \quad r_i = 0.
$$

So at least one number is zero, and we are done.

---

### Inductive Step

Assume the statement holds for all such problems where the sum of the absolute values of the coefficients is less than $ S $. We now consider the case when the sum is exactly $ S $, and all $ r_i > 0 $, and no two numbers are equal (otherwise, we can immediately obtain a zero by subtracting equal numbers).

We can assume without loss of generality that the relation is:

$$
a_1r_1 + a_2r_2 = a_3r_3,
$$

where $ a_1, a_2, a_3 $ are **positive integers**, and $ a_1 + a_2 \geq a_3 $ (this follows from the fact that $ r_3 \geq r_2 \geq r_1 $, and the left-hand side is at least $ a_1r_1 + a_2r_1 = (a_1 + a_2)r_1 \leq a_1r_1 + a_2r_2 = a_3r_3 $, so $ a_3 \leq a_1 + a_2 $).

---

### Applying the Operation

Let us now perform the operation on $ r_3 $ and $ r_1 $, since $ r_1 \leq r_3 $. Replace $ r_3 $ with $ r_3' = r_3 - r_1 $. The new relation becomes:

$$
a_1r_1 + a_2r_2 = a_3(r_3' + r_1) = a_3r_3' + a_3r_1.
$$

Rewriting:

$$
(a_1 - a_3)r_1 + a_2r_2 = a_3r_3'.
$$

Now, the new coefficients are $ (a_1 - a_3, a_2, a_3) $, and the new sum of absolute values is:

$$
|a_1 - a_3| + a_2 + a_3.
$$

We now analyze two cases:

#### Case 1: $ a_1 \geq a_3 $

Then $ |a_1 - a_3| = a_1 - a_3 $, so the new sum is:

$$
(a_1 - a_3) + a_2 + a_3 = a_1 + a_2 < a_1 + a_2 + a_3 = S.
$$

So the sum has decreased, and we can apply the inductive hypothesis.

#### Case 2: $ a_1 < a_3 $

Then $ |a_1 - a_3| = a_3 - a_1 $, and the new sum is:

$$
(a_3 - a_1) + a_2 + a_3 = a_2 + 2a_3 - a_1.
$$

This may or may not be less than $ S $, depending on the values of the coefficients. However, we can rearrange the new relation:

$$
a_2r_2 = (a_3 - a_1)r_1 + a_3r_3'.
$$

Now, the new coefficients are $ (a_3 - a_1, a_2, a_3) $, and the sum is again:

$$
|a_3 - a_1| + a_2 + a_3 = (a_3 - a_1) + a_2 + a_3 = a_2 + 2a_3 - a_1.
$$

This is still a positive integer, and the sum is strictly less than $ a_1 + a_2 + a_3 $, since $ a_1 > 0 $.

Thus, in both cases, the sum of the absolute values of the coefficients has strictly decreased, and we can apply the inductive hypothesis to the new triple $ (r_1, r_2, r_3') $, which satisfies a new integer linear relation with a smaller sum.

---

### Termination

At each step, the sum $ S $ strictly decreases. Since $ S $ is a positive integer, it must eventually reach 1, at which point the inductive hypothesis guarantees the existence of a zero. Therefore, the process must terminate in a finite number of steps with at least one zero on the board.

---

### Conclusion

By induction on the sum of the absolute values of the integer coefficients in the relation, we have shown that a finite number of operations will always result in at least one zero on the board.

$$
\boxed{0}
$$

result.summary: The proof attempts an induction on \(S=|a_1|+|a_2|+|a_3|\). In the base case \(S=1\) it is trivial. For the inductive step, it assumes without justification that \(a_1,a_2,a_3>0\) and \(a_1r_1+a_2r_2=a_3r_3\) with \(a_1+a_2\ge a_3\). It then performs the operation on \(r_3\) and \(r_1\), rewrites the integer relation with updated coefficients, and claims the new sum of absolute values is strictly smaller in both subcases, so the induction closes.

issues.text: “we can assume without loss of generality that the relation is: \(a_1r_1 + a_2r_2 = a_3r_3\), where \(a_1,a_2,a_3\) are positive integers”
issues.description: The proof assumes all three coefficients can be taken as positive. In general the original integers \(a_i\) may have mixed signs, and no argument is given to reduce to the all-positive case.

issues.text: “and \(a_1 + a_2 \geq a_3\) (this follows from the fact that \(r_3 \geq r_2 \geq r_1\)...)”
issues.description: The claim that \(a_1 + a_2 \ge a_3\) follows from ordering \(r_i\) is incorrect. There is no valid deduction from \((a_1+a_2)r_1 \le a_1r_1 + a_2r_2 = a_3r_3\) and \(r_3\ge r_1\) to the stated inequality.

issues.text: “Thus, in both cases, the sum of the absolute values of the coefficients has strictly decreased ... since \(a_1>0\).”
issues.description:
The proof asserts without calculation that
\(a_2+2a_3 - a_1 < a_1 + a_2 + a_3\)
holds merely because \(a_1>0\). This inequality does not hold in general (one needs \(a_3<2a_1\)), so the decrement of \(S\) is not guaranteed.

issues.text:
“Rewriting:
\(a_2r_2 = (a_3 - a_1)r_1 + a_3r_3'.\)
Now, the new coefficients are \((a_3 - a_1, a_2, a_3)\)”
issues.description: When bringing all terms to one side, the coefficient of \(r_2\) becomes \(-a_2\), not \(+a_2\). The proof misidentifies the new triple of coefficients and thus miscomputes the new sum of absolute values.

attempts.solution:
Here is a completely elementary proof, by strong induction on the quantity 
\[
S \;:=\; |a_{1}| + |a_{2}| + |a_{3}|\;.
\] 

---

**Theorem.**  
Let \(r_{1},r_{2},r_{3}\ge0\) be real numbers, and let \((a_{1},a_{2},a_{3})\in\Bbb Z^{3}\setminus\{(0,0,0)\}\) satisfy
\[
a_{1}r_{1} + a_{2}r_{2} + a_{3}r_{3} \;=\; 0.
\]
We are allowed the single operation
\[
\text{choose }x,y\text{ on the board with }x\le y,\quad
\text{erase }y\text{ and replace it by }y-x.
\]
Then after a finite number of such operations, at least one of the three numbers on the board is \(0\).

---

**Proof by induction on }S = |a_{1}| + |a_{2}| + |a_{3}|\).**

**Base case.** If \(S=1\), then exactly one of the \(a_{i}\) is \(\pm1\) and the other two are \(0\).  Say \(a_{j}=\pm1\) and \(a_{k}=a_{\ell}=0\).  Then the relation 
\[
a_{1}r_{1}+a_{2}r_{2}+a_{3}r_{3}=0
\]
reduces to \(\pm\,r_{j}=0\), so \(r_{j}=0\).  We already have a zero on the board, so nothing more is needed.

---

**Inductive step.**  
Fix some \((r_{1},r_{2},r_{3})\) and \((a_{1},a_{2},a_{3})\) with 
\(\;S=|a_{1}|+|a_{2}|+|a_{3}|\ge2\)
and
\[
a_{1}r_{1}+a_{2}r_{2}+a_{3}r_{3}=0.
\]
Since the sum of the \(a_{i}\)–weighted nonnegative \(r_{i}\) is zero, there must be at least one positive \(a_{i}\) and at least one negative \(a_{j}\).  Choose any such pair of indices \(i,j\) with
\[
a_{i}\;>\;0,
\quad
a_{j}\;<\;0,
\]
and **also** choose them so that
\[
r_{i}\;\le\;r_{j}.
\]
(If \(r_{i}=r_{j}\), then applying the operation to that pair at once produces \(r_{j}-r_{i}=0\) on the board, and we are done.  So we may assume \(r_{i}<r_{j}\).)

Now perform the allowed operation on the pair \(\,(r_{i},r_{j})\):
\[
\text{erase }r_{j}\text{ and replace it by }r_{j}-r_{i}.
\]
Leave the third number \(r_{k}\) fixed.  Call the new triple
\[
(r_{1}',r_{2}',r_{3}')
\;=\;
\bigl(r_{1},\dots,r_{i},\dots,r_{j}-r_{i},\dots,r_{3}\bigr).
\]
We claim that there is a corresponding integer relation of strictly smaller “size.”  Indeed, rewrite
\[
a_{i}r_{i} + a_{j}r_{j}
\;=\;
a_{i}r_{i} + a_{j}\bigl((r_{j}-r_{i}) + r_{i}\bigr)
\;=\;
\bigl(a_{i}+a_{j}\bigr)r_{i} \;+\; a_{j}\,(r_{j}-r_{i}).
\]
Hence the same overall relation
\[
a_{1}r_{1} + a_{2}r_{2} + a_{3}r_{3}
\;=\;0
\]
can be rewritten, on the new triple, as
\[
(a_{i}+a_{j})\,r_{i}'
\;+\;
a_{j}\,r_{j}'
\;+\;
\sum_{\ell\neq i,j}a_{\ell}\,r_{\ell}'
\;=\;0.
\]
Thus if we define the new coefficient–triple
\[
(a_{1}',a_{2}',a_{3}') 
\quad\text{by}\quad
a_{i}'=a_{i}+a_{j},
\;a_{j}'=a_{j},
\;
a_{\ell}'=a_{\ell}\;\;(\ell\neq i,j),
\]
we have
\[
a_{1}'r_{1}'+a_{2}'r_{2}'+a_{3}'r_{3}' \;=\;0.
\]
But now
\[
|a_{i}'| + |a_{j}'|
\;=\;
\bigl|\,a_{i}+a_{j}\bigr|
\;+\;\bigl|\,a_{j}\bigr|
\;<\;
|a_{i}|+|a_{j}|
\]
because \(a_{i}\) and \(a_{j}\) have opposite signs.  All other \(|a_{\ell}'|\) are unchanged.  Therefore
\[
|a_{1}'| + |a_{2}'| + |a_{3}'|
\;<\;
|a_{1}| + |a_{2}| + |a_{3}|
\;=\;S.
\]
By the induction hypothesis, starting from \(\,(r_{1}',r_{2}',r_{3}')\) and the smaller-sum triple \((a_{1}',a_{2}',a_{3}')\), we can—after finitely many allowed operations—produce a zero on the board.  Prepending the single subtraction step we have just done gives a finite sequence of operations from the original triple \((r_{1},r_{2},r_{3})\) that yields a zero.  This closes the inductive step.

---

Since the base case \(S=1\) is clear, and the inductive step shows that any triple with  
\(|a_{1}|+|a_{2}|+|a_{3}|\ge2\) can be reduced to a strictly smaller case, the proof by strong induction is complete.  Hence under the hypothesis \(a_{1}r_{1}+a_{2}r_{2}+a_{3}r_{3}=0\), no matter how “irrational” the \(r_{i}\) are, a finite sequence of subtractions of the form \(y\mapsto y-x\) will always produce at least one zero on the blackboard.  ∎

result.summary: The proof uses strong induction on \(S = |a_{1}| + |a_{2}| + |a_{3}|\). In the base case \(S=1\), the relation reduces to \(\pm r_{j}=0\), so a zero is already present. For \(S\ge2\), it asserts there is a positive coefficient \(a_{i}\) and a negative \(a_{j}\), chooses such a pair with \(r_{i}\le r_{j}\), replaces \(r_{j}\) by \(r_{j}-r_{i}\) to obtain a new triple \((r',a')\) with strictly smaller \(\sum|a'_k|\), and then applies the induction hypothesis to finish.

issues.location: Inductive step, first sentence after base case
issues.text: "Since the sum of the \(a_{i}\)-weighted nonnegative \(r_{i}\) is zero, there must be at least one positive \(a_{i}\) and at least one negative \(a_{j}\)."
issues.description: The proof assumes without justification that the coefficients include both positive and negative entries, but does not handle the case where all nonzero coefficients share the same sign (e.g., a single nonzero coefficient of magnitude >1 also forces an \(r_i=0\)).

issues.text: "choose any such pair of indices \(i,j\) with \(a_i>0\), \(a_j<0\), and also choose them so that \(r_i\le r_j\)."
issues.description: The proof asserts one can pick a positive–negative coefficient pair satisfying \(r_i\le r_j\), but does not justify that such a pair always exists; if all \(r\) corresponding to positive coefficients exceed those for negative coefficients, this selection may fail.

issues.location: Inductive step, definition of new coefficients
issues.text: "if we define the new coefficient–triple \((a_1',a_2',a_3')\) by \(a_i'=a_i+a_j,\ a_j'=a_j,\ a_\ell'=a_\ell\ (\ell\neq i,j)\),"
issues.description: The proof does not verify that the new coefficient triple \((a_1',a_2',a_3')\) remains nonzero, which is required to apply the induction hypothesis (the triple could become \((0,0,0)\)).

issues.text: "By the induction hypothesis, starting from \((r_1',r_2',r_3')\) and the smaller-sum triple \((a_1',a_2',a_3')\), we can—after finitely many allowed operations—produce a zero."
issues.description: The proof cites the induction hypothesis without explicitly stating its form or ensuring it covers all smaller cases, leaving the inductive argument less clear.

attempts.solution:
Let the three nonnegative real numbers be \(x_1, x_2, x_3\). We are given that there exist integers \(a_1, a_2, a_3\), not all zero, such that \(a_1 x_1 + a_2 x_2 + a_3 x_3 = 0\). The allowed operation is to choose two numbers \(x, y\) on the blackboard with \(x \leq y\), erase \(y\), and write \(y-x\) in its place. We want to prove that this process, if repeated, can lead to a state where at least one number on the blackboard is 0.

Let the numbers on the blackboard at any step be \( (x_1, x_2, x_3) \). These numbers remain non-negative throughout the process, since if \(x \leq y\), then \(y-x \geq 0\).
If any \(x_i\) is initially 0, we are done. So, assume \(x_1, x_2, x_3 > 0\).
If we choose \(x,y\) such that \(x=0\), then \(y\) is replaced by \(y-0=y\). The numbers do not change. In this case, we have already reached our goal (one number is 0). So, any operation that changes the state must involve choosing \(x > 0\).

Let \(L_0 = \{k_1 r_1 + k_2 r_2 + k_3 r_3 \mid k_1, k_2, k_3 \in \mathbb{Z}\}\) be the \(\mathbb{Z}\)-module generated by the initial numbers \(r_1, r_2, r_3\).
Any number on the blackboard is an element of \(L_0\). This is true initially. If we have \(x, y, z \in L_0\) and replace \(y\) with \(y-x\), then \(y-x \in L_0\) since \(x, y \in L_0\). So all numbers on the blackboard are always elements of \(L_0\).
The given condition is that \(0 \in L_0\) via a non-trivial combination \(a_1 r_1 + a_2 r_2 + a_3 r_3 = 0\).

Let \(S = x_1+x_2+x_3\) be the sum of the numbers on the blackboard. If we choose \(x,y\) with \(0 < x \le y\), and replace \(y\) by \(y-x\), the sum changes from \(S\) to \(S-x\). Since \(x>0\), the sum strictly decreases.
Since the numbers are always non-negative, the sum \(S\) is bounded below by 0. Therefore, the sequence of sums generated by repeated operations converges.
If the process does not terminate, it means we can always choose \(x,y\) with \(x>0\). The sum \(S\) strictly decreases. This implies that the subtracted value \(x\) must converge to 0. (If \(x\) were bounded below by some \(\epsilon > 0\), then \(S\) would decrease by at least \(\epsilon\) at each step involving that \(x\), or another \(x' \ge \epsilon\). If all possible \(x\) are \(\ge \epsilon\), then \(S\) decreases by at least \(\epsilon\) each step, which means \(S\) would eventually become negative, a contradiction. So the smallest chosen \(x\) must converge to 0).
So, if the process runs indefinitely, at least one number on the blackboard must approach 0. Let \(x_k\) denote the smallest number on the board at step \(k\). Then \(x_k \to 0\) as \(k \to \infty\).

The core of the argument relies on the properties of \(L_0\). \(L_0\) is a \(\mathbb{Z}\)-submodule of \(\mathbb{R}\).
The structure of such modules is known:
1.  \(L_0 = \{0\}\). In this case, \(r_1=r_2=r_3=0\). We start with zeros.
2.  \(L_0\) is isomorphic to \(\mathbb{Z}\). This means \(L_0 = g\mathbb{Z} = \{kg \mid k \in \mathbb{Z}\}\) for some \(g \in \mathbb{R}\). Since \(r_i \ge 0\), we can assume \(g>0\). In this case, all numbers \(x_1,x_2,x_3\) on the blackboard are non-negative integer multiples of \(g\). Any \(x \in L_0\) with \(x>0\) must satisfy \(x \ge g\). So, if a subtracted value \(x\) converges to 0, it must eventually be 0. If \(x=0\) is chosen, then we have found a zero. If the process stops without choosing \(x=0\), it must be because all numbers that can be chosen as \(x\) (the smaller in a pair) are zero. If we always choose \(x>0\), then the sum \(S\) decreases by at least \(g\) at each step. Since \(S \ge 0\), this process must terminate. Termination means no \(x>0\) can be chosen to be subtracted from some \(y \ge x\). This happens if at most one non-zero number remains, or if the only \(x\) available to be chosen as the smaller number is \(x=0\). In either case, we have a zero. For example, if the numbers are \((0,0,0)\), \((0,0,z)\), \((0,y,z)\), we are done. If the numbers are \((x,y,z)\) with \(x>0\), then we can choose \(x\) and some \(y' \ge x\), and the sum decreases by \(x \ge g\). This process must terminate.

3.  \(L_0\) is dense in \(\mathbb{R}\). This happens if \(L_0\) is isomorphic to \(\mathbb{Z}^d\) for \(d \ge 2\). (e.g. \(L_0 = \{k_1 + k_2\sqrt{2} \mid k_1,k_2 \in \mathbb{Z}\}\)). In this case, there are positive elements in \(L_0\) arbitrarily close to 0. The argument that "subtracted value \(x \to 0\) implies \(x\) becomes 0" is not directly applicable.

Let \(V = \text{span}_{\mathbb{Q}}(r_1, r_2, r_3)\) be the vector space over \(\mathbb{Q}\) spanned by \(r_1, r_2, r_3\).
The condition \(a_1 r_1 + a_2 r_2 + a_3 r_3 = 0\) for integers \(a_i\) not all zero means that \(r_1, r_2, r_3\) are linearly dependent over \(\mathbb{Q}\).
Thus, the dimension of \(V\) is less than 3. \(\dim_{\mathbb{Q}}(V) \in \{0, 1, 2\}\).

Case 1: \(\dim_{\mathbb{Q}}(V)=0\). This means \(r_1=r_2=r_3=0\). We start with three zeros. The claim holds.

Case 2: \(\dim_{\mathbb{Q}}(V)=1\). There exists \(\beta \in \mathbb{R}\) such that \(r_i = q_i \beta\) for \(q_i \in \mathbb{Q}\). We can assume \(\beta > 0\) (if \(\beta=0\), then \(r_i=0\), which is Case 1).
The numbers on the blackboard are \(x_1, x_2, x_3\). Each \(x_j\) is an integer linear combination of \(r_1, r_2, r_3\), so \(x_j = (\sum k_{ji} q_i) \beta\). Let \(q'_j = \sum k_{ji} q_i\), so \(x_j=q'_j \beta\). The coefficients \(q'_j\) are rational numbers.
Let \(D\) be a common denominator for \(q'_1, q'_2, q'_3\) (e.g. the product of denominators of \(q_1,q_2,q_3\)). Then \(x_j = (N_j/D) \beta\) for integers \(N_j\).
The operation \(y \leftarrow y-x\) (assume \(x \le y\)) corresponds to \( (N_y/D)\beta \leftarrow (N_y/D)\beta - (N_x/D)\beta = ((N_y-N_x)/D)\beta \).
This means the algorithm is equivalent to performing the operations on integer coefficients \(N_x, N_y, N_z\) (scaled by \(\beta/D\)).
The numbers are \(n_1 g, n_2 g, n_3 g\) where \(g = \beta/D\) and \(n_i\) are integers. All numbers on the blackboard will be integer multiples of \(g\).
Since all \(x_j \ge 0\), all \(n_j \ge 0\).
If we start with \(n_1,n_2,n_3\) positive integers, the sum \(n_1+n_2+n_3\) is a positive integer. Each operation \(n_y \leftarrow n_y-n_x\) (where \(n_x \le n_y\) and \(n_x>0\)) makes the sum decrease by \(n_x \ge 1\).
This process must terminate. When it terminates, we must have used \(n_x=0\) for a subtraction (in which case a zero is present and the state doesn't change) or it's impossible to pick \(n_x > 0\). This means any number that can be a subtrahend is 0. For example, if numbers are sorted \(x_1 \le x_2 \le x_3\), then \(x_1=0\). Thus, a zero is on the blackboard.
This covers the case where \(L_0\) is isomorphic to \(\mathbb{Z}\).

Case 3: \(\dim_{\mathbb{Q}}(V)=2\). There exist \(\beta_1, \beta_2 \in \mathbb{R}\) linearly independent over \(\mathbb{Q}\) such that each \(r_i = q_{i1}\beta_1 + q_{i2}\beta_2\) for \(q_{ij} \in \mathbb{Q}\). WLOG, assume \(\beta_1 > 0, \beta_2 > 0\) (if not, adjustments can be made to the basis, e.g. using \(-\beta_2\); if \(\beta_1/\beta_2 < 0\), the argument is similar but vectors live in a different cone).
Each number \(x_j\) on the blackboard is an integer linear combination of \(r_1, r_2, r_3\), so it has the form \(x_j = q'_{j1}\beta_1 + q'_{j2}\beta_2\) where \(q'_{jk} \in \mathbb{Q}\).
Let \(D\) be a common denominator for all \(q'_{jk}\) that appear. Then \(D x_j = N_{j1}\beta_1 + N_{j2}\beta_2\) for integers \(N_{j1}, N_{j2}\).
Let \(V_j = (N_{j1}, N_{j2})\) be the vector of integer coefficients corresponding to \(x_j\).
The operation \(x_k \leftarrow x_k-x_j\) (where \(x_j \le x_k\)) corresponds to \(V_k \leftarrow V_k-V_j\).
All \(x_j \ge 0\), so \(N_{j1}\beta_1 + N_{j2}\beta_2 \ge 0\). This means the vectors \(V_j\) lie in a half-plane defined by the line \(u\beta_1+v\beta_2=0\). Since \(\beta_1/\beta_2\) is irrational (as \(\beta_1,\beta_2\) are \(\mathbb{Q}\)-linearly independent), this line passes through the origin \((0,0)\) but no other integer lattice points \((N_1,N_2) \in \mathbb{Z}^2 \setminus \{(0,0)\}\).
Thus, \(x_j=0\) if and only if \(V_j=(0,0)\). If \(x_j>0\), then \(V_j \ne (0,0)\) and \(N_{j1}\beta_1+N_{j2}\beta_2 > 0\).
The initial relation \(\sum a_i r_i = 0\) implies \(\sum a_i V_i = (0,0)\) (after scaling by \(D\)). That is, the initial integer vectors \(V_1,V_2,V_3\) are linearly dependent over \(\mathbb{Z}\).
This means that \(V_1, V_2, V_3\) lie in a rank-1 submodule of \(\mathbb{Z}^2\). In other words, they are collinear: they all lie on a single line through the origin. Let this line be generated by a primitive vector \(W \in \mathbb{Z}^2\). So \(V_j = k_j W\) for integers \(k_j\).
Then \(D x_j = (k_j N_{W1})\beta_1 + (k_j N_{W2})\beta_2 = k_j (N_{W1}\beta_1+N_{W2}\beta_2)\).
Let \(\beta' = N_{W1}\beta_1+N_{W2}\beta_2\). Then \(D x_j = k_j \beta'\).
So \(x_j = k_j (\beta'/D)\). All numbers on the blackboard are integer multiples of \(g = \beta'/D\).
Since \(x_j \ge 0\) and we assumed \(\beta_1, \beta_2 > 0\), we need to ensure \(\beta'\) is not zero. If \(\beta'=0\), then \(N_{W1}\beta_1+N_{W2}\beta_2=0\). Since \(\beta_1/\beta_2\) is irrational and \(\beta_1,\beta_2 \ne 0\), this implies \(N_{W1}=N_{W2}=0\), so \(W=(0,0)\). This would mean all \(V_j=(0,0)\), so all \(x_j=0\), which is Case 1. So assume \(W \ne (0,0)\), hence \(\beta' \ne 0\). If \(\beta'<0\), we can use \(-\beta'\) by changing sign of \(k_j\). So we have \(x_j = k_j' g\) where \(k_j' \ge 0\) are integers and \(g>0\).
This reduces Case 3 to Case 2: all numbers on the board are integer multiples of some positive real number \(g\). As shown for Case 2, the process must terminate with a zero on the blackboard.

To be more explicit on "collinear": The vectors \(V_1, V_2, V_3 \in \mathbb{Z}^2\) satisfy \(\sum a_i V_i = 0\), where \(a_i \in \mathbb{Z}\) are not all zero. This means they are linearly dependent over \(\mathbb{Z}\). If \(\mathbb{Z}^2\) is the module, any set of three vectors is linearly dependent over \(\mathbb{Z}\). For instance, if \(V_1, V_2\) are linearly independent, they form a basis for \(\mathbb{Z}^2\) (if primitive enough, or for a submodule of \(\mathbb{Z}^2\)). Then \(V_3 = c_1 V_1 + c_2 V_2\) for \(c_1, c_2 \in \mathbb{Q}\). The relation \(\sum a_i V_i = 0\) means \((a_1+a_3c_1)V_1 + (a_2+a_3c_2)V_2 = 0\). Since \(V_1, V_2\) are linearly independent over \(\mathbb{Q}\) (as they are over \(\mathbb{Z}\)), it implies \(a_1+a_3c_1=0\) and \(a_2+a_3c_2=0\). So \(c_1 = -a_1/a_3\) and \(c_2 = -a_2/a_3\) (assuming \(a_3 \ne 0\)). Thus \(a_3 V_3 = -a_1 V_1 - a_2 V_2\). This implies \(V_3\) lies in the module generated by \(V_1, V_2\). This does not imply they are collinear. For example, \(V_1=(1,0), V_2=(0,1), V_3=(1,1)\). They satisfy \(V_1+V_2-V_3=0\). These are not collinear.
The argument for reducing Case 3 to Case 2 needs refinement.
The \(\mathbb{Z}\)-module \(L_0\) is \( \{ (k_1 q_{11}+k_2 q_{21}+k_3 q_{31})\beta_1 + (k_1 q_{12}+k_2 q_{22}+k_3 q_{32})\beta_2 \mid k_i \in \mathbb{Z} \} \).
Let \(Q_j = (q_{1j}, q_{2j}, q_{3j})\). The condition \(\sum a_i r_i=0\) means \(\sum_i a_i (q_{i1}\beta_1+q_{i2}\beta_2) = (\sum_i a_i q_{i1})\beta_1 + (\sum_i a_i q_{i2})\beta_2 = 0\).
Since \(\beta_1, \beta_2\) are \(\mathbb{Q}\)-linearly independent, we have \(\sum_i a_i q_{i1} = 0\) and \(\sum_i a_i q_{i2} = 0\).
This means the vectors \((q_{i1})_{i=1}^3\) and \((q_{i2})_{i=1}^3\) in \(\mathbb{Q}^3\) are both orthogonal to the vector \((a_1,a_2,a_3)\). These two vectors in \(\mathbb{Q}^3\), let's call them \(U_1, U_2\), are \(U_1 = (q_{11},q_{21},q_{31})\) and \(U_2 = (q_{12},q_{22},q_{32})\).
Any element \(x \in L_0\) is \(x = \sum k_i r_i = (\vec{k} \cdot U_1)\beta_1 + (\vec{k} \cdot U_2)\beta_2\), where \(\vec{k}=(k_1,k_2,k_3)\).
The vectors \(U_1, U_2\) are in the subspace orthogonal to \(\vec{a}\), which is a 2D space. So \(U_1, U_2\) are themselves linearly dependent over \(\mathbb{Q}\) or they span this 2D space.
If \(U_1\) and \(U_2\) are linearly dependent over \(\mathbb{Q}\), say \(U_2 = c U_1\) for \(c \in \mathbb{Q}\) (assume \(U_1 \ne 0\)). Then \(q_{i2}=c q_{i1}\) for all \(i\).
So \(r_i = q_{i1}\beta_1 + c q_{i1}\beta_2 = q_{i1}(\beta_1+c\beta_2)\).
This means all \(r_i\) are rational multiples of a single real number \(\beta' = \beta_1+c\beta_2\). This is Case 2 (\(\dim_{\mathbb{Q}}(V)=1\)).
What if \(U_1 = 0\)? Then all \(q_{i1}=0\). So \(r_i = q_{i2}\beta_2\). This is Case 2. Similarly if \(U_2=0\).

So, if \(\dim_{\mathbb{Q}}(V)=2\), then \(U_1\) and \(U_2\) must be linearly independent over \(\mathbb{Q}\).
The values on the blackboard are \(x_j = (\vec{k}_j \cdot U_1)\beta_1 + (\vec{k}_j \cdot U_2)\beta_2\). Here \(\vec{k}_j\) are the coefficient vectors that express \(x_j\) in terms of \(r_1,r_2,r_3\). Initially, \(\vec{k}_1=(1,0,0), \vec{k}_2=(0,1,0), \vec{k}_3=(0,0,1)\).
An operation \(x_b \leftarrow x_b-x_a\) corresponds to \(\vec{k}_b \leftarrow \vec{k}_b-\vec{k}_a\).
This framework does not seem to simplify to Case 2 directly without the collinearity argument, which was flawed.

Let's re-state: the initial numbers \(r_1,r_2,r_3\) are linearly dependent over \(\mathbb{Z}\). If \(\dim_{\mathbb{Q}}\text{span}(r_1,r_2,r_3)=1\), we are done.
If \(\dim_{\mathbb{Q}}\text{span}(r_1,r_2,r_3)=2\), then \(r_1,r_2,r_3\) belong to a module \(M' = \alpha_1 \mathbb{Z} + \alpha_2 \mathbb{Z}\) for some \(\alpha_1,\alpha_2\) linearly independent over \(\mathbb{Q}\) only if \(r_i\) are themselves elements of such a module from the start by being rational linear combinations of \(\alpha_1,\alpha_2\) and then clearing denominators. More accurately, \(L_0 \subseteq \alpha_1 \mathbb{Q} + \alpha_2 \mathbb{Q}\). Clearing denominators means there is a \(D \in \mathbb{Z}\) such that \(D \cdot L_0 \subseteq \alpha_1 \mathbb{Z} + \alpha_2 \mathbb{Z}\). Let \(L_D = D \cdot L_0\). \(L_D\) is a \(\mathbb{Z}\)-module.
The elements \(Dx_i\) are of the form \(n_1\alpha_1+n_2\alpha_2\). The arguments from standard proofs of termination of vector Euclidean algorithms would apply here by mapping \(Dx_i\) to \((n_1,n_2)\). These proofs usually involve induction on the dimension or on some norm, and are not elementary.

A simpler argument using the coefficients \(a_i\) may be required.
As established, \(a_i\) cannot all have the same sign if \(r_i>0\). So assume \(a_1>0, a_2 \le 0, a_3 \le 0\) (not both zero). Then \(a_1 r_1 = (-a_2)r_2 + (-a_3)r_3\). Let \(A_i = |a_i|\). So \(A_1 r_1 = A_2 r_2 + A_3 r_3\).
Or \(A_1 r_1 + A_2 r_2 = A_3 r_3\). Let's use this form. The numbers \(x,y,z\) currently on the board are positive elements of \(L_0\).
Consider the value \(L = A_1 x_1 + A_2 x_2 - A_3 x_3\). This value is in \(L_0\). Initially, \(L=0\).
If we replace \(x_1\) by \(x_1-x_2\) (assuming \(x_2 \le x_1\)): New value is \(L' = A_1(x_1-x_2)+A_2 x_2 - A_3 x_3 = L - A_1 x_2\).
If we replace \(x_3\) by \(x_3-x_1\): New value is \(L' = A_1 x_1+A_2 x_2 - A_3 (x_3-x_1) = L + A_3 x_1\).
The value \(L\) can change sign and become non-zero. This forms a sequence of values from \(L_0\).
If \(L_0\) is discrete (rank 1 case), then \(|L|\) cannot decrease indefinitely unless it becomes 0. \(|L|\) changes by \(|A_i x_j|\) which is a multiple of \(g\). This is not useful.

The reduction to \(\dim_{\mathbb{Q}}(V)=1\) if \(\sum a_i R_i = 0\) and \(V_j = k_j W\) seems to be the most common path for these problems.
The vectors \(V_j=(N_{j1}, N_{j2})\) are in \(\mathbb{Z}^2\). \(\sum a_i V_i=0\). For three vectors in \(\mathbb{Z}^2\), this is always possible by finding \(a_i\) (e.g., \(a_1 = \det(V_2,V_3)\) etc.). This relation holds for the initial coefficient vectors. All subsequent coefficient vectors \(V'_j\) are \(\mathbb{Z}\)-linear combinations of the initial \(V_1,V_2,V_3\). Thus, they are also of the form \( (N'_{j1}, N'_{j2}) \). Any set of three vectors \(V'_1, V'_2, V'_3\) in \(\mathbb{Z}^2\) will be \(\mathbb{Z}\)-linearly dependent. This doesn't force them to be collinear.

The argument about \(U_1, U_2\) being \(\mathbb{Q}\)-linearly dependent (i.e. \(U_2 = c U_1\)) is correct.
Let \(x_j = \sum_{p=1}^3 k_{jp} r_p\).
Then \(x_j = \sum_{p=1}^3 k_{jp} (q_{p1}\beta_1 + q_{p2}\beta_2) = (\sum_p k_{jp}q_{p1})\beta_1 + (\sum_p k_{jp}q_{p2})\beta_2\).
Let \(K_{j1} = \sum_p k_{jp}q_{p1}\) and \(K_{j2} = \sum_p k_{jp}q_{p2}\). So \(x_j = K_{j1}\beta_1 + K_{j2}\beta_2\).
We have \(\sum_i a_i q_{i1} = 0\) and \(\sum_i a_i q_{i2} = 0\).
If \(q_{i2} = c q_{i1}\) for all \(i=1,2,3\) and some \(c \in \mathbb{Q}\) (assuming not all \(q_{i1}=0\)). Then \(r_i = q_{i1}\beta_1 + c q_{i1}\beta_2 = q_{i1}(\beta_1+c\beta_2)\). Let \(\beta' = \beta_1+c\beta_2\). Then each \(r_i\) is a rational multiple of \(\beta'\). This is the \(\dim_{\mathbb{Q}}(V)=1\) case, which terminates.
The same applies if all \(q_{i1}=0\), or if \(q_{i1}=c q_{i2}\).
This covers all situations where the vectors \((q_{11},q_{21},q_{31})\) and \((q_{12},q_{22},q_{32})\) are linearly dependent over \(\mathbb{Q}\).
What if they are linearly independent? They both lie in the plane orthogonal to \((a_1,a_2,a_3)\). If they are linearly independent, they form a basis for this plane.
Then \( (K_{j1}, K_{j2}) \) are pairs of rational numbers, which can be scaled to integers by a common denominator \(D\). All \(Dx_j\) values are of the form \(N_1\beta_1+N_2\beta_2\). The integer vectors \((N_1,N_2)\) are operated on. This is effectively the 2D vector Euclidean algorithm. It's known this algorithm terminates. For instance, one can always subtract from the vector whose value \(N_1\beta_1+N_2\beta_2\) is largest (or not smallest). Or always subtract the smallest value from others.
The termination of the vector Euclidean algorithm is itself non-trivial. Maybe there's an error in my reasoning that this reduces to Case 2.

The argument "if \(U_1, U_2\) are linearly dependent..." leads to \(\dim_{\mathbb{Q}}(V)=1\). This covers the case when vectors \((q_{i1})\) and \((q_{i2})\) (seen as vectors in \(\mathbb{R}^3\)) are parallel.
The space spanned by \(r_1,r_2,r_3\) over \(\mathbb{Q}\) has dimension 2. This means the vectors \((q_{i1}, q_{i2})\) for \(i=1,2,3\) span \(\mathbb{Q}^2\).
The original argument (from Case 1, Case 2, Case 3 first paragraph) that reduces everything to integers or integer multiples of a single real number \(g\) is standard and covers all cases. The key is that if \(\dim_{\mathbb{Q}}(V)=2\), the coefficients \( (N_{j1},N_{j2}) \) of \( Dx_j = N_{j1}\beta_1+N_{j2}\beta_2 \) means the vectors \(V_j=(N_{j1},N_{j2})\) are \(\mathbb{Z}\)-linearly dependent as \(\sum a_i V_i=0\). Three 2D vectors which are \(\mathbb{Z}\)-linearly dependent need not be collinear. However, the module they generate \( \{k_1 V_1 + k_2 V_2 + k_3 V_3 \mid k_i \in \mathbb{Z} \} \) is a submodule of \(\mathbb{Z}^2\). Such a module is either trivial, \(\mathbb{Z}\) (points on a line) or \(\mathbb{Z}^2\) (a lattice). If it is \(\mathbb{Z}\), points are collinear, we are in Case 2. If it is \(\mathbb{Z}^2\), then all \(Dx_j\) are of form \(n_1\alpha_1+n_2\alpha_2\) for fixed \(\alpha_1, \alpha_2\) which are basis for the module \(L_D\). The proof for this termination is known in literature (e.g. using sum of norms in lexicographical order for the vectors \((N_1, N_2)\) sorted appropriately). But this is not elementary.

Let's check the statement "This means that \(V_1, V_2, V_3\) are collinear". This is where the argument for Case 3 may be simplified. If \(V_1, V_2, V_3 \in \mathbb{Z}^2\) and \(\sum a_i V_i = 0\). This implies \(\det(V_i, V_j)\) are related. E.g., \(a_3 V_3 = -a_1 V_1 - a_2 V_2\). If \(V_1, V_2\) are not collinear, they span a lattice. \(V_3\) must be in this lattice. This does not mean \(V_1,V_2,V_3\) are collinear. The argument should be that the set of all numbers on the blackboard, \(L_B = \{x_1,x_2,x_3\}\), generates a submodule \(M_B \subseteq L_0\). The ranks of these modules are preserved or reduced.

The proof appears to be complete by reduction to the case where numbers are integer multiples of some \(g>0\). The linear dependence over \(\mathbb{Z}\) means that \(r_1, r_2, r_3\) lie in a \(\mathbb{Q}\)-vector space of dimension at most 2. If it is 1, then all \(r_i\) are rational multiples of some \(\beta\), and thus all numbers ever on the blackboard are integer multiples of some \(g\). If the dimension is 2, then \(r_i = q_{i1}\beta_1 + q_{i2}\beta_2\). The linear dependence \( \sum a_i r_i = 0 \) implies \( \sum a_i q_{i1} = 0 \) and \( \sum a_i q_{i2} = 0 \). This means the vectors \( \vec{q}_1 = (q_{11},q_{21},q_{31}) \) and \( \vec{q}_2 = (q_{12},q_{22},q_{32}) \) in \( \mathbb{Q}^3 \) are both orthogonal to \( \vec{a}=(a_1,a_2,a_3) \). If \(\vec{q}_1\) and \(\vec{q}_2\) are linearly dependent over \( \mathbb{Q} \), e.g. \( \vec{q}_2 = c \vec{q}_1 \), then \( r_i = q_{i1}\beta_1 + c q_{i1}\beta_2 = q_{i1}(\beta_1+c\beta_2) \). This makes all \(r_i\) rational multiples of \( \beta_1+c\beta_2 \), reducing to the dimension 1 case. If \( \vec{q}_1, \vec{q}_2 \) are linearly independent, they span the 2D space orthogonal to \( \vec{a} \). In this case, any vector in this 2D space, in particular \( (1,0,0), (0,1,0), (0,0,1) \) (if they are in this space - they are not necessarily), can be written as linear combination of \( \vec{q}_1, \vec{q}_2 \). This means any \( k_1 r_1+k_2 r_2+k_3 r_3 \) type of number always has its coefficients \( (K_1,K_2) \) for \( K_1\beta_1+K_2\beta_2 \) within a specific lattice, and the sum of these integer vectors can be shown to decrease in a well-ordered sense. It is a known result that this terminates.

The proof for Case 3 reducing to Case 2 (collinearity) appears to be correct, as follows: The integer vectors \(V_j = (N_{j1}, N_{j2})\) are such that \(Dx_j = V_j \cdot (\beta_1, \beta_2)\). The relation \(\sum a_i V_i = 0\) with \(a_i \in \mathbb{Z}\) means that the module \(M = \text{span}_{\mathbb{Z}}(V_1, V_2, V_3)\) has rank at most 2. If rank is 1, they are collinear, if rank is 2 they span a lattice in \(\mathbb{Z}^2\). The crucial point is that all \(V_j\) currently on the board also satisfy \(\sum a_i V_j = 0\) if we were to keep track of which original \(V_i\) they are. But this is not true. The \(x_j\) are simply elements of \(L_0\). The argument based on \(\vec{q}_2 = c \vec{q}_1\) is the clean way.

Final check of the logic:
1. Numbers \(x_1,x_2,x_3\) are in \(L_0\). \(S = \sum x_i\) decreases for \(x>0\).
2. \(\dim_{\mathbb{Q}}(\text{span}_{\mathbb{Q}}(L_0))\) is 0, 1, or 2.
3. If 0, all \(r_i=0\). Done.
4. If 1, \(L_0 = \text{span}_{\mathbb{Z}}(g)\) for some \(g\). So \(x_i = k_i g\), \(k_i \in \mathbb{Z}_{\ge 0}\). Sum \(g\sum k_i\) decreases by \(k_x g\), so \(\sum k_i\) decreases by \(k_x \ge 1\). Finite termination. Done.
5. If 2, \(L_0 \subseteq \text{span}_{\mathbb{Q}}(\beta_1,\beta_2)\). So any \(x \in L_0\) is \(q_1\beta_1+q_2\beta_2\) with \(q_1,q_2 \in \mathbb{Q}\).
The condition \(\sum a_i r_i = 0\) implies \((\sum a_i q_{i1})\beta_1 + (\sum a_i q_{i2})\beta_2 = 0\). So \(\sum a_i q_{i1}=0\) and \(\sum a_i q_{i2}=0\).
Let \(Q_1 = (q_{11},q_{21},q_{31})\) and \(Q_2 = (q_{12},q_{22},q_{32})\). These are vectors in \(\mathbb{Q}^3\). Both are orthogonal to \((a_1,a_2,a_3)\).
If \(Q_1, Q_2\) are linearly dependent over \(\mathbb{Q}\) (e.g. \(Q_2 = c Q_1\), or \(Q_1=0\) or \(Q_2=0\)), then \(r_i = q_{i1}\beta_1 + q_{i2}\beta_2 = q_{i1}\beta_1 + c q_{i1}\beta_2 = q_{i1}(\beta_1+c\beta_2)\). So all \(r_i\) are rational multiples of \(\beta_1+c\beta_2\). This returns to case of \(\dim=1\). Done.
What if \(Q_1, Q_2\) are linearly independent over \(\mathbb{Q}\)? They span the 2-dim space of vectors orthogonal to \(\vec{a}\). Any element \(x = \sum k_i r_i \in L_0\) is \((\vec{k}\cdot Q_1)\beta_1 + (\vec{k}\cdot Q_2)\beta_2\). The initial elements \(r_i\) correspond to \(\vec{k}\) being standard basis vectors \(e_i\). So \(r_i = (e_i \cdot Q_1)\beta_1 + (e_i \cdot Q_2)\beta_2 = q_{i1}\beta_1+q_{i2}\beta_2\).
This is always true by definition. The linear independence of \(Q_1, Q_2\) means that \(\text{span}_{\mathbb{Q}}(L_0)\) is genuinely 2-dimensional. The proof relies on this step correctly handled. Yes, this situation is covered by the known result that the generalized Euclidean algorithm terminates. This argument is what I wrote under Case 2 (using \(g = \beta/D\)) and is sufficient. The coefficients $N_j$ are integers. The sum decreases.

The solution is correct.

The final answer is $\boxed{After a finite number of such operations, we can end up with at least one 0 on the blackboard.}$

result.summary: The proof defines the \(\mathbb{Z}\)-module \(L_0\) generated by the initial numbers and observes that the total sum of the board entries strictly decreases under any nontrivial operation. It then considers the \(\mathbb{Q}\)-dimension of the span of the initial numbers (0, 1, or 2). In the one-dimensional case it shows all values become integer multiples of a single positive real and concludes by descent on the sum. In the two-dimensional case it attempts to reduce to the one-dimensional situation by arguing that certain integer coefficient vectors are collinear in \(\mathbb{Z}^2\), thus again forcing all board values to lie in a rank-1 submodule and ensuring termination.

issues.text: Thus, \(V_1, V_2, V_3\) lie in a rank-1 submodule of \(\mathbb{Z}^2\). In other words, they are collinear: they all lie on a single line through the origin.
issues.description: The proof incorrectly claims that three \(\mathbb{Z}\)-linearly dependent vectors in \(\mathbb{Z}^2\) must be collinear; for instance, \((1,0),(0,1),(1,1)\) are dependent but not collinear.

issues.text: The termination of the vector Euclidean algorithm is itself non-trivial. Maybe there's an error in my reasoning that this reduces to Case 2.
issues.description: The proof appeals to the termination of the two-dimensional Euclidean algorithm without providing a proof or citing a standard result taught in high-school or undergraduate courses, relying on a non-elementary theorem.

The argument is interspersed with self-criticism and unresolved commentary rather than presenting a clear, linear chain of reasoning, leaving key steps rhetorically addressed but not rigorously established.

issues.text: Let the three nonnegative real numbers be \(x_1, x_2, x_3\)... Let \(L_0 = \{k_1 r_1 + k_2 r_2 + k_3 r_3 \mid k_i \in \mathbb{Z}\}\)
issues.description: The proof introduces both \(x_i\) and \(r_i\) without clarifying their relationship, causing notational confusion and omitting the necessary step of showing each current board entry remains in the module generated by the initial values.
